body:
## Welcome to Food Forest Info
First time here?  [Learn about us](/article/intro)
## How to help
If you like this site and want to help out, [we have some suggestions](/article/contribute).

articles.name: How to Contribute
body: ## How Can You Help?

At this time we are not quite ready to accept help directly from the community (unless you can code, then see us on [GitHub](https://github.com/jdmarshall/foodforest)). There are other ways you can help us all in the meantime.
## Pictures

Good pictures of plants are going to be one of the hardest things to come by.  If you have access to plants and a good eye, start taking pictures.  We'll need them soon, but it'll take some time before we can accept uploads.
## Volunteer

Nothing beats hands-on experience helping with an existing Food Forest Project.  In exchange for your time you will learn a lot about plants and help build something at the same time.  Find a local project, or one you can visit.
#### United States
* Seattle Washington:  [Beacon Food Forest](http://www.beaconfoodforest.org/)
Do you know of a project not listed here? [Contact us](https://github.com/jdmarshall/foodforest/issues/new)

articles.name: An Introduction
body: ## Food Forests Explained
On this site, we hope to connect people who want to learn about plants with the people who understand them.  We'll
use plain language, presented in easily digested pieces.  We hope when you're done that you will want to try growing
your own. We want to help you with that, too.
There's a common problem on the Internet.  You want to learn about something new, but everything you find is written
by experts who seem to be used to talking to other experts.  Words you don't know.  'Explanations' that only lead to
more questions and little understanding.  Details that seem out of place or just too much.  It's a rare person who
can take a complicated subject and make the rest of us understand it.  They may not be the smartest or most
knowledgeable people in their field, but their contributions are often very important.
More questions?  See our [Frequently Asked Questions](/article/faq)

articles.name: Frequently Asked Questions
body: ## What is a Food Forest?
A Food Forest is pretty much what it sounds like:  A lot of plants, most of them with parts you can eat.
There are a lot of different names for this concept, but 'food forest' is by far the simplest.
## What is Permaculture?
If a Food Forest is *what* you have, Permaculture is *how* you get it.  It's a philosophy and a set of
practices intended to create gardens or farms that contain a wide variety useful plants, and which resemble what we
think of as 'Nature'.
In fact, what many of us think of as 'Nature' has rarely been the natural state of things.  Indigenous peoples the
world over have been using sophisticated land management practices for millenia, and while this has been documented
for a long time, it is only in recent years that these facts are being recognized.  Even the forests that John Muir
so famously loved were largely the product of the First Peoples of California.
In permaculture you start with the soil.  Other than water, it's the most important element in a successful
project.  You fill the soil with plants that fill a variety of roles. The plants complement each other, sometimes in
very complicated ways. Then you care for the plants in a way that takes care of the soil and is in keeping with the
role the plant fulfills. Permaculture works with the plants, not against them. If something isn't
happy, you don't fight it.  You move on and try something else.
